document.masterDocTitle: Further studies on the fairy shrimp genus Branchinella (Crustacea: Anostraca: Thamnocephalidae) in Australia, with descriptions of five new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks.
Branchinella affinis
occurs across Australia (
Timms, 2004
) and is one of the more variable
Branchinella
species (
Geddes, 1981
). This variability is partly documented by
Geddes ( 1981 )
to which must now be added the slightly different form of
B. clandestina .
In a molecular analysis of the 16 SmtDNA region,
Pinceel et al . ( 2012 )
found the genetic difference between
B. clandestina
and
B. affinis
to be only 1.8 %, far less than a difference> 4 % that
Adamowicz & Purvis ( 2005 )
and
Adamowicz et al . ( 2009 )
claim to differentiate species for rDNA coding genes. The diagnostic features of
B. clandestina
, namely the unusually narrow frontal appendage, its branching at about 5 / 6 ths the length, limited sensory papillae on the frontal appendage branches, and the curving in three planes of the basal segment of the second antennae (
Timms, 2005
) should now be considered as further variations in morphology of
B. affinis
. The egg is not different (
Fig. 1
B), but then eggs of
B. affinis
are not distinctive (Timms and Lindsay, 2011 ). All of these variations have been seen in recent years in various degrees in specimens from many sites across Australia , including those listed in the materials from areas not previously collected. For instance, the two specimens from near Wilcannia, New South Wales , have claspers shaped like those in the
B. clandestina
, but otherwise would be considered
B. affinis
sensu stricto . So,
B. clandestina
is regarded as a junior synonym of
B. affinis
. Further work, especially using molecular techniques, is needed to understand variation within this taxon. The description of
B. erosa
sp. nov .
below is the first attempt at this.
